Posts.Content: number5 wrote: Well, the doc came in this am and said 'ta-da'.  Obviously it was good.  The pathologist had walked it up right before my appt, and the corpsman knew why I was there and that I was nervous, so he told me if I needed anything, just to let him know. So, I guess the little cysts that were on the mass made it look questionable on the mammo & u/s, plus to the surgeon:  BENIGN BREAST TISSUE WITH FIBROADENOMATOID AND FIBROCYSTIC CHANGES INCLUDING APOCRINE METAPLASIA-whew! I know that you can all understand my relief.  I can't thank you all enough for being so supportive and encouraging the past couple of weeks-it really means a lot.  I'm going to take a break from here, but I wish you ALL the best of health and well wishes.  You will all be in my thoughts and prayers for your continued strength! Thank you all again.  Pace, Jamie Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: GREAT news!! number5 liz19

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 09:24AM number5 wrote: Well, saw the surgeon today and she fit me into to OR tomorrow.  The radiologist will put the needle wire in, then it's up to OR for some happy juice and surgery. The surgeon was great, and didn't poo-poo any of my questions regardless of the fact that we know nothing except for fact the I need a biopsy.  She was very understanding about me needing to know my options 'just in case'-the logistics and our military insurance are the tricky parts!  We'll see! She said depending on if the pathologist was in country or not, would depend on when I got the results back.   She did tell me she'd set up an appt to see her regardless of the results. I'll keep you posted.  Ciao e pace!!!
Posts.Title: Seeing surgeon tomorrow! number5 number5

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 09:12AM number5 wrote: Ciao All!  I had my biopsy this am.  The radiologist inserted the wire with the needled (fortunately I didn't feel a thing), and then it was up to the APU to wait for the OR.  I think the worst pain was the insertion of the IV needle-and even that wasn't much. Everything went well in there-and the lump/mass was closer to the surface-which made the excision much quicker.  The surgeon wouldn't dare tell me what she thought one way or the other.  She said she did that once and would never do it again-of course I completely understand.  The pathologist said he'd have the results by next Wed or Thursday, so I just need to call tomorrow to set up an appt with the surgeon for Thursday. Regardless of the fact of what may or may not show up, I feel so lucky to have a great hospital staff here.  A lot of it has to do with all of us being military and whatnot, but being that we are such a small community, I'm sure it makes it that much more helpful.  Oh, the lump was just over 1 cm, and the doctor did say there were tiny cysts attached to it.  I'm just going to try and not worry-try being the operative word here.  So far I'm not having any pain-and I hope that holds out. I'll keep you posted.  Ciao e pace!!
Posts.Title: Seeing surgeon tomorrow! number5 number5

Posts.Content: number5 wrote: I updated my original post, but I couldn't change the subject line.  At any rate, I had my ultrasound on Friday the 4th, and I've been referred to general surgery for a consult tomorrow. The radiologist said it wasn't a cyst, and he could see calcifications with the mass.   He also said that it wasn't 'agressive', for whatever that means.  As I posted in my other thread, I didn't like the look on his face, and of course we both did discuss the less than 20% that are actual positive for b/c. So, it's off to the other doc tomorrow, and then we just go from there.  My husband and I are of course hoping for the best, but aren't naive enough to not expect the worst.  We already have made contingency plans for 'just in case.'   Being that we are overseas with the government/military, a little extra planning for us weighs hugely on our minds. Anyway, I'll let you know when I know.  Ciao e pace!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Seeing surgeon tomorrow! number5 number5

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2008 11:19AM number5 wrote: "If I do have to have chemo and or radiation is it sommon that people can continue to work? I just bought a house, im single and dont have log term disability. I know that is putting the cart before the horse but I am worried about that part of it" My sister would have to take a couple of days off right after chemo, but she continued to work.  She is also single (now), and owns her own home after her divorce.  Also, she never had children (though not because she didn't try during her nearly 2 decade marriage), and for her because of her proximity to menopause, the chemo put her in complete menopause (she was 44 when diagnosed). I know that I read recently that it is possible to still have children after chemo, though I'm sure, like everything else, it depends on the person. We (my husband and I), went through many years of infertility before we adopted our eldest, and then we were finally able to go through IVF-which was successful.  I don't know how much egg harvesting costs, but that is something you could look into.  As for being an adoptive Mom, that was the most rewarding experience of my life-that was the day I became a Mommy. I hope I don't sound like I'm lessening your feelings regarding having a child-I'm not-but I do know the joy of parenting through adoption.  It truly is a beautiful thing. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: I have surgery on Monday Deidre flower123

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 05:43PM number5 wrote: I haven't posted to you before, but I have my fingers crossed that all is well!  I'm sitting here in Italy figuring out the hour of when you go to the Dr's office-which should be soon!  You are in my prayers as well as your family!!! Jamie
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, thank u everyone Sparkysbrat Sparkysbrat

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 10:49AM number5 wrote: I had one 3 years ago at the age of 43!  I think I have a pretty high pain threshhold, so I wasn't bothered too much!  The worst part for me was the adhesive strip they put on the incision-apparently I have a bit of an allergy to it-who knew? I was up and around in no time-I have four young boys, so I really didn't have a choice! Good luck and take care!
Posts.Title: Fibroadenoma Removal Surgery? Candro Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 02:09AM number5 wrote: I should probably add more info-my apologies!!  kdbartelo:  I am getting American help.  I'm going through the US Navy hospital here in Italy, but we don't have a breast MRI machine, therefore I have to go to an Italian hospital-one of the best in southern Italy. My biggest thought/concern, was that the radiologist focused on the calcifications (of which I had a few last year), and said that was the reason why I needed the MRI!  I should have asked more questions, but I was just bummed that he called me after the corpsmen told me I was good to go! I'm worried but not worried-if that makes sense. One of my sisters is a four year survivor and going strong-she is my strength and inspiration in knowing that IF there were to be anything wrong, I can follow her lead. I'm venting on here because I don't want to worry my family, and also, I've been going through that anxiety for unknown reasons (like life isn't full of reasons). Thanks for the support folks.  I'll let you all know what happens tomorrow, and of course what the results are!  Pace, Jamie
Posts.Title: Here I go again-now an MRI! number5 number5

Posts.Content: May 5, 2009 07:25AM number5 wrote: I'm still here.  I checked with radiology yesterday to find out what the procedure was for getting my results:  The Tricare Office (our insurance located in the hospital), will get the results and are supposed to have a phone consult with the requesting provider. I have an appt at the hospital tomorrow, so I'll track down my PCM and ask her if she has heard anything.  They are usually pretty good about everything, but because I had to go to an Italian hospital and the next day was a holiday, I'm not waiting around to 'see' if they call.  Being that ours is a small military hospital overseas, I can do everything in one place! I'm not really worried, but I'd still like to know.  The radiologist said that if something showed up I'd probably have to have another biopsy.  With my Mom coming into town this Friday, I want to know before she gets here so I can schedule it all for when she's gone.  She's been down this road with one of my sisters, and I don't want to cause her undo worry (like having to have a procedure while she's in town). When I know something I'll let you all know.  Ciao e grazie!  Jamie
Posts.Title: Here I go again-now an MRI! number5 number5

Posts.Content: number5 wrote: Hello folks.  I was here last year before, during and after a breast biopsy that was b9!  I had my annual mammo done a few weeks ago, and now I have need to have an MRI! After the mammo with our new digital machine, the Navy Corpsmen came back and said all was okay (re the radiologist).  Thought cool, and headed to our NEX-then my cell rings.  It's the radiologist saying that there were calcifications, and because of my previous biopsy and my sister having had breast cancer, I needed to have an MRI!  What stuck out in my mind was because of the calcifications. I promptly went home and looked them up and realized that MRI's don't do much for calcifications!  I could always call the radiologist, though he is the only one we have at our Navy hospital here.  My provider seemed not too worried.  Before and during this time, I've been experiencing major anxiety (for the first time in my life), which has made all of this stay in the back of my mind!!! On Thursday I will go to our hospital and be taken to the Italian hospital that has the equipment (fortunately the Navy will have a translator there the whole time). I guess I'm just not sure why I need this (MRI), and I'm sort of irritated with myself for not asking more questions.  So, I guess I'll let you all know.  BTW, I'm 43! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Here I go again-now an MRI! number5 number5

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 07:53AM number5 wrote: I'm back.   Other than having a headache right now (which I'm not sure is from the MRI), all went well.   I read my consult sheet and it said that I was recommended for the MRI because of heterogenously dense breast and because of my sister being diagnosed at 44!  I also had a biopsy last year which was for a b9 fibro(sp? the rest of it), and that mammo also showed some calcifications.  I've had more than a few mammo's because of a cyst that was finally drained once my sister was diagnosed. So, now it's a wait and see.  Tomorrow is Italian Labor Day, so hopefully I'll get the results sometime next week.  I'm hoping sooner rather than later as my Mom & step father are arriving next Friday for a vacation! Thanks for the support and l'll let you all know.
Posts.Title: Here I go again-now an MRI! number5 number5

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 09:40AM number5 wrote: Ciao again!  I would never discourage anybody from using fertility drugs-they helped make my dream come true!:-)  I wonder though if there is something there that some of us have in us that is triggered by certain things!  We never know if we're allergic to something until we are exposed, yet that's how we find out-but we still go about our lives before that, even though we know other people are allergic! I too would like to see some study or the other regarding this-though I'm afraid if they did one, people would back away from the dream of getting pregnant with the use of fertility drugs! These are the things I think of when I'm pondering the why BC has affected so many people! Grazie!! J
Posts.Title: Fertility drug connection??? number5 NicolaSue

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 11:08AM number5 wrote: I just had mine today-not sure if it will leave a scar or not.  My surgeon did tell me yesterday that she'd prefer to go through the areola as it's not as noticable. Of course I'm of the mind that as long as they get what they need and for the reason they do-I'm not worrying about scarring!  Just think that about what is best for you in the long run. Good luck!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 11:44AM number5 wrote: Hey clueless, I'm with you!:)  No, no cup for me-though that would have been interesting.  As far as I know they just taped it down-I couldn't feel a thing.  They wheeled me down in a wheel chair from the APU using the back elevators, though I did have to wait in the general waiting room until the u/s room was open.  That would have been interesting if someone came in the I knew.  I just sat there with my IV.  After the needle insertion, I went back to the waiting room for a corpsman from the APU to come back and get me.  A mom had to explain to her little boy what was hanging down my arm and why I was wearing my nifty gown and lovely cotton blankey!:)  The poor guy sitting across from me was trying desparately not to look.  If it weren't for an entirely serious reason, it would really be quite funny! The pain for me is pretty much gone, and I didn't wear a bra to bed last night-aaahhh!  The steri strips are still in place (it was the adhesive bandage they put over it that cause the itching), and I'm a bit bruised-but no pain.  We'll see what the doc has to say tomorrow-hopefully all will be fine. Take care!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 09:45AM number5 wrote: @Selenawolf:  Knock on wood, my three IVF boys are doing just fine-thank goodness!  My twins (who will be 12 in 2 weeks), were born 8 weeks premature, but you'd never know it by looking at them (even at birth).  My youngest will be 9 next week, and he too is doing very well!  I was told many years ago that IVF babies had a tendency to have more health/educational issues, but I don't know if that's because there are more multiples during one pregancy with many IVF pregnancies-or what the deal is!  My boys have thankfully thrived, as well as my eldest who was adopted at birth!  Now I have a new teen, and two on the edge!  Mamma mia! :-) J
Posts.Title: Fertility drug connection??? number5 NicolaSue

Posts.Content: number5 wrote: Hello all!  Since reading so many different forums regarding pain in BC (such as docs saying you don't get pain in BC), being 'too young' to get BC, and other sorts of dismissive things docs say-and the uninformed in general! Let me begin by saying I do NOT have breast cancer!  I've had breast issues the past three years with having a surgical biopsy (B9), microcalcifications, and most recently (yesterday), scheduling a diagnostic mammogram because something showed up on my annual mammo last Thursday!  I've had a cyst for many years that prompted a mammogram at the age of 23-it was finally drained after my sisters BC diagnosis 7 years ago!  I'm 46 now!! Which brings me to my subject:  How many on here that are dealing with BC, used fertility drugs?  I have 3 sisters (and 5 bros), and my sister is the ONLY person in our entire family (cousins,aunts, uncles,etc.,) that has had any form of cancer!  She and I both used fertility drugs-our other two sisters and Mom had no problems conceiving naturally, and alas, none of them have had any issues when it comes to the breasts! Now I know that hormones are a big factor!  I'm personally on BHRT progesterone after having blood and saliva test that showed my progesterone very, very low, and my estrogen 300 times that of my progesterone!  But does all of this, plus fertility drugs play a role? Going back, my sister and former BIL went through several rounds of IUI-both with my BIL's sperm (which was a low count), and with donor sperm-no avail!  I used Clomid for several months, did 4 rounds of IUI, and then one round (very successful-three babies later), of IVF!  That's A LOT of hormones all at once-and my body knew it! So, anybody else out there feel there's a connection?  Don't get me wrong, if I had to I'd do it all over again, but I just wonder if there IS a connection!  Thanks for reading! J Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fertility drug connection??? number5 NicolaSue

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 06:22AM number5 wrote: "Hi number 5-maybe you are allergic to a component of the tape or adhesive? I've done that before, and sometimes it comes and goes. Some tapes contain latex, though more and more items are latex free. (Latex is a relatively common allergen." It must be a new kind of adhesive.  I've had 3 laparoscopies & a c-section, plus a few minor things that required taping/adhesive, though I've never had a problem before.  Of course the APU nurse, admissions nurse, etc., all asked me if I had an allergy to it, of course it was no, so I'm guessing it's something new.  When I go back next week I'm going to find out what brand they used so I know for whatever reason NOT to have it again.  Crikey, it itches.  The Corpsman at the surgery said neosporin on the itchy site would be okay and if it got worse I could just go into the hospital later. Other than that all is well.:)  Got a sitter for the night and my husband & I are going to have a 'quiet' dinner-just the two of us. clueless:  Do you fee any better about the surgery?  I hope things are going well for you!  Pace!!!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 04:37AM number5 wrote: A bra is a must afterwards.  I'm a 38D (although the surgeon said that my breast weren't very large-they aren't when I'm lying down and they are in my armpits).  I wore a looser sports bra home from the hospital, but the band underneath kept bothering me, so I swtiched to one of my underwire bras-that is so much more comfortable for me. I took a shobath this am (that's what my boys & I call a bath using the mobile shower nozzle).  I just kept a washcloth over the tape/bandage, but it was a little uncomfortable trying to manuever.  All in all it hasn't been that bad. Pace!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Title: Fertility drug connection??? number5 NicolaSue

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 12:21PM number5 wrote: Hiya!  My incision is about 1.5 inches, and about 6:30, and it's covered with the steri-strips.  I really didn't have much pain the first few days, but it's a little more achy now-mostly when I get up in the morning.  I have a pretty high tolerance for pain, so I'll I needed was just regular Tylenol. I tried my sports bras, but they were way too tight.  My regular everyday bras have worked well.  I will admit that my boob looks bruised, but I'm not sure if that is from the surgery or when the radiologist was inserted the needle for the wire-he tried twice.  The surgeon even made a joke that if I had a bruise, it was all the radiologists' fault.:) All in all it hasn't been too bad!  Let us know how it goes!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 02:53AM number5 wrote: Ultrasound guided. Mine was also closer to the surface, which ironically, made it more difficult for the radiologist to put the needle.  I guess it's easier if it has to go deeper???  They numbed the areas and I didn't feel a thing.!!!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 11:34AM number5 wrote: I'm doing well-thank you.  I just took some regular Tylenol-though they did give me a prescription for #3.  I'm not a big fan of painkillers outside of Tylenol. It just started feeling a little bit 'stingy' about a 1/2 hour ago-my surgery was at 1100 here in Italy and it's now 5:33 pm!  Actually most of the pain is from underneath where they had the sticky stuff-my boob keeps getting stuck to the skin on my rib cage. Take care!!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 05:07PM number5 wrote: I'm doing well-thank you.  My incision may not be as large as others, so that might make a difference.  I did take the bandage of tonight (though I was supposed to wait until tomorrow), because it was itching me like crazy. I've had 4 abdominal surgeries previously (infertility stuff and a c-section), and I never had any problem with anything-I guess this time it's different.  I actually tore some skin off and have blisters on another part where the bandage was (I have the steristrips over the stitches). Other than that it's going well.  Thank you for asking!  Pace!
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2
